column3:
Were highpoints of our Sons and Lovers phase.
The midnight fire. The paschal candlestick.
Elbow to elbow, glad to be kneeling next

Took to wearing a smudge on their foreheads
To be prepared for whatever. Vigils
Began to be kept around puddled gaps,

Counting bells knelling classes to a close.
At two o’clock our neighbours drove me home.
In the porch I met my father crying—

In hers and coughed out angry tearless sighs.
At ten o’clock the ambulance arrived
With the corpse, stanched and bandaged by the nurses.

Dawn-sniffing revenant,
Plodder through midnight rain,
Question me again.

The Guttural Muse
Late summer, and at midnight
I smelt the heat of the day:

He lived there in the unsayable lights.
He saw the fuchsia in a drizzling noon,
The elderflower at dusk like a risen moon

Collapse into a sibilant penumbra.
Midnight and closedown. Sirens of the tundra,
Of eel-road, seal-road, keel-road, whale-road, raise

Inviolable and affronting.
He felt the glass go cold in the midnight sun.
When he staggered up and smashed it on the stones

And we lifted our eyes to the nouns.
Altar stone was dawn and monstrance noon,
the word ‘rubric’ itself a bloodshot sunset.

Late summer, and at midnight
Leaving the white glow of filling stations
